repnme.cdata!:
Central African Republic - Multisectoral
            HIV/AIDS, Health, and Education Emergency Support Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Multisectoral HIV/AIDS,
            Health, and Education Emergency Support Project for Central
            African Republic (CAR) were as follows: outcomes were
            moderately satisfactory; risk to development outcome was
            moderate; Bank performance was moderately satisfactory; and
            borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned includes: strong ownership and the
            commitment of key actors could leverage significant funding
            and ensure continuity in the government and partner efforts
            even under circumstances that do not allow for normal
            operation. The case of CAR demonstrated this in two ways.
            First, the project faced more than five years of suspension
            before effectiveness but the government was still able to
            make full use of project advances and Trust Funds that were
            exceptionally granted to strengthen its institutional
            capacity, and as a result, leveraged large amount of
            resources from different partners. Second, once the decision
            on re-engagement was made, the World Bank team and the
            government moved swiftly with the project preparation
            capitalizing on what had been built in the preceding years,
            while adjusting the design and implementation mechanism to
            meet the actual needs. A strategy shift in 2007 from a
            single HIV/AIDS operation to a multifaceted one encompassing
            broader social sectors promoted a higher response to needs
            in diverse areas. In addition, synergies were created to
            ensure efficient use of resources. A clear, well-defined
            institutional arrangement from the outset is crucial to
            achieving optimal results in a multisectoral operation.
            Stakeholders agreed that part of the initial implementation
            delays were caused by ambiguity in their division of roles
            and responsibilities, given the complexity of the project
            set-up and the numerous parties involved. Some of
            project's creative approaches for fiduciary
            arrangements could provide important lessons in a context of
            political instability and post-conflict situations. Use of
            Civil-Society Organizations (CSOs) needs to be accompanied
            by a realistic capacity assessment and support for capacity
            strengthening. The project underscored the great benefits of
            civil society involvement and empowerment of communities in
            responding to their own needs and reaching out to the most
            remote areas; however, adequate technical capacity of these
            organizations needs to be ensured.

repnme.cdata!:
Central African Republic - Multisectoral
            HIV/AIDS, Health, and Education Emergency Support Project
            Restructuring : environmental and social assessment

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the
            Multisectoral HIV/AIDS, Health, and Education Emergency
            Support Project is to help the Government reduce HIV/AIDS,
            prevalence in the Central Africa Republic (CAR), and to
            mitigate the impact of HIV/AIDS on persons infected with or
            affected by HIV/AIDS. This environmental and social
            assessment (EA) document evaluated project impacts and
            presents recommendations and mitigation measures, as follows
            : elaborate a document defining the national policy, norms
            and regulations for better control of the disposal of
            medical wastes; organize information campaigns to educate
            the project affected peoples (PAPs) on the dangers of
            collecting or making use of medical waste items, such as
            syringes and sharps instruments; to reduce the effects of
            excessive noise, unloading bays, refuse disposal areas,
            boiler houses, workshops, laundry and kitchen areas should
            placed far from hospital sensitive areas; establish a yearly
            monitoring and follow-up program for the correct
            implementation of the program for the disposal of medical
            waste at the national, regional and local level; bio-medical
            waste will be placed in sealed drums and taken to
            appropriate places for disposal; waste water from toilets
            and bathrooms will be treated prior to discharged in to
            ground or natural drains; and finally, in general, adhere to
            Central Africa Republic (CAR),'s legislation, codes of
            public health, and international conventions relative to
            health services (OMS, UNICEF and UNDP of which Central
            Africa Republic (CAR), is a signatory, and the Bank's
            operational safeguard directives on health, nutrition and
            population, all workers engaged in hospital and medical
            handling and disposal will be regularly examined for
            infectious diseases; and finally, maintain a continuous
            dialog with the local population keeping them informed
            project implementation stages.

repnme.cdata!:
Central African Republic - Multisectoral
            HIV/AIDS, Health, and Education Emergency Support Project Restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The original objectives of the
            Multisectoral HIV/AIDS, Health, and Education Emergency
            Support Project were to help the Government reduce HIV/AIDS,
            prevalence in the Central Africa Republic (CAR), and to
            mitigate the impact of HIV/AIDS on persons infected with or
            affected by HIV/AIDS. The main reasons for the project
            restructuring are: new emergencies resulting from civil
            disturbances and developments since original project
            approval and because HIV-AIDS remains a major problem in
            CAR. The revised project development objectives (PDO)
            reflect on today's understanding that the
            Multi-sectoral AIDS Program (MAP) projects cannot use
            prevalence rates as impact indicators. The revised PDO would
            be to contribute to meeting (a) urgent needs in the fight
            against HIV, such as access to prevention, treatment, and
            impact mitigation services (b) urgent social needs such as
            prevention of malaria, increased access to water supply and
            improved primary education. The project components and
            subcomponents would reflect the new objectives, addressing
            HN/AIDS, health and education emergency needs. The
            restructured project would include a component for each
            sector, plus a component for a small financial management
            and procurement unit.
